_meta.notes: All descriptions based on published peer-reviewed literature

Proxima Cen b.description: A rocky world orbiting our nearest stellar neighbor, just 4.2 light-years away. Located in the habitable zone of Proxima Centauri, though the red dwarf's intense flares may challenge habitability.

TRAPPIST-1 b.description: The innermost planet of the remarkable TRAPPIST-1 system, where seven Earth-sized worlds orbit a cool red dwarf. Too hot for liquid water, but part of the most compact planetary system known.

TRAPPIST-1 c.description: Second planet in the TRAPPIST-1 system. Recent JWST observations suggest it has little to no atmosphere, providing key data about rocky planet evolution around red dwarfs.

TRAPPIST-1 d.description: The smallest planet in the TRAPPIST-1 system, located at the inner edge of the habitable zone. A prime target for atmospheric characterization with JWST.

TRAPPIST-1 e.description: Often considered the most habitable candidate in the TRAPPIST-1 system. Similar size and temperature to Earth, receiving comparable stellar flux. A top priority for biosignature searches.

TRAPPIST-1 f.description: A cool, potentially icy world in the outer habitable zone of TRAPPIST-1. May have retained significant water if it migrated from farther out in the disk.

TRAPPIST-1 g.description: The largest planet in the TRAPPIST-1 system, slightly bigger than Earth. Located in the outer habitable zone, potentially a cold world with subsurface oceans.

TRAPPIST-1 h.description: The outermost known planet in the TRAPPIST-1 system. Too cold for surface liquid water, but tidal heating from its resonant orbit may provide internal warmth.

51 Peg b.notableReason: First exoplanet discovered around a Sun-like star
51 Peg b.description: The planet that launched a revolution. Discovered in 1995 using radial velocity, this 'hot Jupiter' challenged all models of planet formation by orbiting impossibly close to its star. Nobel Prize in Physics 2019.

Kepler-22 b.notableReason: First Kepler planet in habitable zone
Kepler-22 b.description: The first planet discovered by Kepler in the habitable zone of a Sun-like star. About 2.4 times Earth's size, its composition remains uncertain—possibly a mini-Neptune or ocean world.

Kepler-442 b.notableReason: One of the most Earth-like planets known
Kepler-442 b.description: A super-Earth in the habitable zone with one of the highest Earth Similarity Index scores. At 1.3 Earth radii and receiving similar stellar flux to Earth, it's a compelling analog to our world.

Kepler-452 b.description: Often called 'Earth 2.0,' this planet orbits a G-type star similar to our Sun at nearly the same distance Earth orbits. At 1.6 billion years older, it offers a glimpse at Earth's possible future.

Kepler-186 f.notableReason: First Earth-sized planet in habitable zone
Kepler-186 f.description: A milestone discovery: the first truly Earth-sized planet found in the habitable zone. Orbiting a red dwarf, it demonstrated that Earth-sized worlds exist at the right distances for liquid water.

HD 209458 b.notableReason: First transiting exoplanet, first atmosphere detected
HD 209458 b.description: A record-breaking world: first exoplanet seen transiting its star, first with a detected atmosphere, first with measured atmospheric escape. This hot Jupiter enabled the birth of exoplanet atmospheric science.

GJ 1214 b.description: A super-Earth with a thick atmosphere that may be rich in water vapor. Its low density suggests it could be a 'water world' with a steam atmosphere, or a mini-Neptune with a hydrogen envelope.

55 Cnc e.description: A scorching super-Earth that orbits its star in just 18 hours. Surface temperatures exceed 2000K—hot enough to melt rock. JWST has detected possible volcanic activity.

HR 8799 b.description: One of four giant planets directly photographed orbiting HR 8799. This system provided the first images of multiple planets around another star, revolutionizing our understanding of outer planetary systems.

HR 8799 c.description: A massive giant planet in the HR 8799 system. Direct imaging allows detailed spectroscopy, revealing clouds and atmospheric chemistry impossible to study in transiting hot Jupiters.

HR 8799 d.description: The third planet discovered in the HR 8799 system. The four planets are locked in a resonant chain, with orbital periods in near-perfect integer ratios.

HR 8799 e.description: The innermost and last-discovered planet in the HR 8799 system. Its atmosphere has been studied in detail, showing evidence of disequilibrium chemistry and clouds.

beta Pic b.notableReason: Young giant planet in famous debris disk
beta Pic b.description: A young, hot giant planet embedded in the famous Beta Pictoris debris disk. At only ~20 million years old, it offers a snapshot of planetary system formation in action.

LHS 1140 b.description: A dense, rocky super-Earth in the habitable zone of a nearby red dwarf. Its high density suggests an iron-rich composition, and it transits its quiet host star—ideal for atmospheric studies.

K2-18 b.description: A sub-Neptune in the habitable zone that made headlines when JWST detected carbon-bearing molecules in its atmosphere. The controversial detection of dimethyl sulfide sparked debate about potential biological origins.

TOI-700 d.notableReason: First TESS Earth-sized habitable zone planet
TOI-700 d.description: TESS's first Earth-sized planet in a habitable zone. This world orbits a cool M dwarf and demonstrated TESS's capability to find small, potentially habitable worlds.

Kepler-16 b.description: A real-life Tatooine: the first planet confirmed to orbit two stars. This Saturn-sized world experiences double sunsets, proving that circumbinary planets can form and survive.

PSR B1257+12 b.description: One of the first exoplanets ever discovered, orbiting a millisecond pulsar. These planets may have formed from the debris of the supernova that created the pulsar—a truly alien origin.

PSR B1257+12 c.description: Part of the first planetary system discovered beyond our Sun. Though inhospitable, these pulsar planets proved that planet formation is ubiquitous in the galaxy.

WASP-12 b.notableReason: Planet being consumed by its star
WASP-12 b.description: A doomed hot Jupiter so close to its star that it's being tidally shredded. The planet is losing mass and spiraling inward; in a few million years, it will be consumed entirely.

WASP-76 b.description: An ultra-hot Jupiter where it rains iron. The day side is hot enough to vaporize iron, which condenses into droplets on the cooler night side, falling as metallic rain.

OGLE-2005-BLG-390L b.description: One of the coldest exoplanets known, discovered via gravitational microlensing. This frozen super-Earth, 21,500 light-years away, demonstrated microlensing's power to find distant, cold worlds.

Kepler-90 h.description: The outermost planet in an 8-planet system that briefly tied our Solar System for most planets known. Discovered with machine learning, it showed AI's potential in exoplanet science.

Kepler-11 b.description: Part of a remarkably compact system where six planets orbit closer than Venus orbits the Sun. These 'peas in a pod' systems challenged theories of planetary spacing and migration.

Gliese 12 b.description: A nearby temperate world receiving similar energy to Venus. At just 40 light-years away, it's close enough for detailed atmospheric study and may hold clues about Earth-sized planet evolution.
